<h2>At a glance</h2>
<ul>
    <li>Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death for women. Cardiovascular conditions in the United States make up at least a third of the women’s health gap because of inequities between women and men in care delivery, efficacy, and data availability. </li>
    <li>Addressing heart health at every life stage can improve a woman’s quality of life and overall health. It could lead to at least 1.6 million years of higher-quality life and boost the US economy by $28 billion annually by 2040.</li>
    <li>In the United States, Black women have a higher prevalence of and morbidity from CVD than non-Black women do.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>In the United States,</strong> cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death for women. Today, more than 60 million women are living with CVD.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="73a80ee3-0f5f-450b-a2fe-1a8323998021"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="73a80ee3-0f5f-450b-a2fe-1a8323998021" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“About women and heart disease,” US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), May 15, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> They’re more likely than men to die from a heart attack and to develop heart failure in the five years after discharge from the hospital.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fe042dba-cb81-4748-bd17-873fd8575e41"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fe042dba-cb81-4748-bd17-873fd8575e41" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Justin A. Ezekowitz et al., “Is there a sex gap in surviving an acute coronary syndrome or subsequent development of heart failure?,” <em>Circulation</em>, December 2020, Volume 142, Number 3.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/lucy-perez">Lucy Pérez</a> and <a href="/our-people/megan-ann-greenfield">Megan Greenfield</a> of the McKinsey Health Institute and leaders of the American Heart Association.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>CVD makes up over a third of the health gap between US men and women, as measured in potential years of healthy life (Exhibit 1). Analysts have quantified this gap in terms of disability-adjusted life years. Building on previous research from the McKinsey Health Institute and the World Economic Forum on <a href="/mhi/our-insights/closing-the-womens-health-gap-a-1-trillion-dollar-opportunity-to-improve-lives-and-economies">the women’s health gap</a>,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d15eef8b-a78e-4aab-8537-995f17ba4416"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d15eef8b-a78e-4aab-8537-995f17ba4416" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The women’s health gap is the disease burden associated with inequities between women and men in intervention efficacy, care delivery, and data. The women’s health burden reflects conditions that affect women disproportionately or differently than they do men.</span></span></span></a></span> additional insights have found that the United States has the potential to gain an additional $28 billion in GDP by 2040 by closing the gap in heart health between men and women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b9f431f6-e9ed-477a-bfe4-6096e895b077"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b9f431f6-e9ed-477a-bfe4-6096e895b077" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">This number likely underestimates the additional gains from reduced maternal mortality and downstream effects of neonatal morbidity, mortality, and long-term health.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Opportunity for cardiovascular health makes up a large part of the US women’s health gap." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Women constitute half of the population, workforce, and community and are responsible for over 80 percent of a family’s medical decision making. Therefore, their well-being plays a pivotal role in shaping the overall health of families and communities. Enabling women to be healthier sets in motion a ripple effect of positive cardiovascular-health choices in the public, private, and social sectors that can lead to a healthier population, including for caregivers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="40bc1ea4-7a78-4588-9e10-9110eb3cc094"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="40bc1ea4-7a78-4588-9e10-9110eb3cc094" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Laura Williamson, “Families often have chief medical officers – and they’re almost always women,” American Heart Association (AHA), April 17, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Addressing women’s heart health and reducing CVD risk factors also has potential financial benefits for employers. One study estimated that the per-year price of employee absenteeism costs a large employer from around $17,000 for diabetes to more than $285,000 for physical inactivity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a8e35425-962a-47eb-ba71-847088ef88d3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a8e35425-962a-47eb-ba71-847088ef88d3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Garrett R. Beeler Asay et al., “Absenteeism and employer costs associated with chronic diseases and health risk factors in the US workforce,” <em>Preventing Chronic Disease</em>, October 2016, Volume 13.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<!-- -->
<p>CVD presents differently in women and men. Yet a pervasive one-size-fits-all mentality for it remains throughout the healthcare delivery ecosystem. Research revealed that only 22 percent of physicians and 42 percent of cardiologists felt extremely well prepared to adequately assess CVD specific to women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0b1f4677-3f6a-4652-bb36-c62ae99034ac"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0b1f4677-3f6a-4652-bb36-c62ae99034ac" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">C. Noel Bairey Merz et al., “Knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs regarding cardiovascular disease in women: The Women’s Heart Alliance,” <em>Journal of the American College of Cardiology</em>, July 2017, Volume 70, Number 2. </span></span></span></a></span>
</p>
<p>Caring for heart health should be a priority throughout a woman’s lifespan, not just at older ages when acute symptoms are most prevalent and most expected by women themselves. It’s possible to address modifiable risk factors and focus on prevention before CVD sets in. For example, four out of five maternal deaths are preventable. Considering that CVD remains the leading cause of maternal deaths, this overlap indicates that addressing prevention can lower maternal mortality related to CVD.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="77a91562-2e72-4e40-aa82-d5d2c362a7cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="77a91562-2e72-4e40-aa82-d5d2c362a7cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Four in 5 pregnancy-related deaths in the U.S. are preventable,” CDC press release, September 19, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The women’s heart health gap in the United States is addressable by providing sex- and gender-appropriate cardiac care and research. This can be supported by investments, innovation, education, and public-awareness campaigns.</p>
<p>By addressing the CVD gap between men and women in the United States, women could live longer and higher-quality lives, potentially regaining 1.6 million years of life lost because of poor health and early deaths.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="50d99e69-b37b-4c74-96fd-c39cbea22f9f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="50d99e69-b37b-4c74-96fd-c39cbea22f9f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anouk Petersen, Lucy Pérez, Brad Herbig, and Pooja Tatwawadi, “<a href="/mhi/our-insights/bridging-the-womens-health-gap-a-country-level-exploration">Bridging the women’s health gap: A country-level exploration</a>,” McKinsey, May 23, 2024. </span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<h2>Women are biologically different from men</h2>
<p>A woman’s cardiovascular health is influenced by biological factors that are rooted in unique life stages. Women and men share many traditional risk factors for the development of CVD, such as obesity, smoking, and diabetes. But the relative impact of these may vary because of biological differences and behavioral practices. For example, literature suggests that although men have a higher prevalence of diabetes than women do, the presence of diabetes increases cardiovascular risk by three- to sevenfold in women, compared with a two- to threefold increase in men.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2c38ad70-33d8-4536-9e44-fbd7d595f79e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2c38ad70-33d8-4536-9e44-fbd7d595f79e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Aardra Rajendran et al., “Sex-specific differences in cardiovascular risk factors and implications for cardiovascular disease prevention in women,” <em>Atherosclerosis</em>, November 2023, Volume 384. </span></span></span></a></span> Men have a higher prevalence of CVD, but women are more likely to die after having an acute cardiovascular event.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b97e327c-d96f-4713-9b11-685e3d53ee64"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b97e327c-d96f-4713-9b11-685e3d53ee64" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Satyam Suman, Jakkula Pravalika, Pulluru Manjula, and Umar Farooq, “Gender and CVD: Does it really matter?,” <em>Current Problems in Cardiology</em>, May 2023, Volume 48, Number 5.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Estrogen, a sex hormone, is believed to have a protective effect on the heart and may potentially explain some of the differences. Estrogen plays a role in regulating various metabolic functions, such as lipid levels (amounts of fat) in the blood, inflammatory markers (contributing to damage to vessel walls), and the coagulant system (affecting blood clot formation).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5d52ffe7-6aa6-42bf-8a69-48e081ce8092"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5d52ffe7-6aa6-42bf-8a69-48e081ce8092" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">A.H.E.M. Maas and Y.E.A. Appelman, “Gender differences in coronary heart disease,” <em>Netherlands Heart Journal</em>, December 2010, Volume 18.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, estrogen is believed to help relax and open up blood vessels throughout the body, allowing for better blood flow. </p>
<p>The understanding of biological differences such as these has expanded, but major knowledge gaps still exist. Heart health—or lack thereof—affects not only the cardiovascular system but the whole body, including the gastrointestinal, immune, musculoskeletal, neurological, pulmonary, and renal systems. For example, midlife hypertension is associated with an approximately 60 percent increased risk of all-cause dementia, and systolic hypertension (systolic blood pressure greater than 160 millimeters of mercury) is associated with an approximately 25 percent increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f0a6c5c0-3ea5-4620-b922-277f4030f5d4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f0a6c5c0-3ea5-4620-b922-277f4030f5d4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Matthew J. Lennon et al., “Use of antihypertensives, blood pressure, and estimated risk of dementia in late life: An individual participant data meta-analysis,” <em>JAMA Network Open</em>, September 2023, Volume 6, Number 9; Matthew J. Lennon et al., “Midlife hypertension and Alzheimer’s disease: A systematic review and meta-analysis,” <em>Journal of Alzheimer’s Disease</em>, 2019, Volume 71, Number 1.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>By 2040, brain health and heart health together could contribute to nearly half of the US women’s health burden gap (or two million years of life lost each year because of poor health or early death).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="866289d1-f277-4234-951c-702bd0e6c8db"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="866289d1-f277-4234-951c-702bd0e6c8db" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Health Institute (MHI) research. </span></span></span></a></span> Improving brain health and heart health together could add over $100 billion in annual US GDP by 2040. Addressing CVD throughout a woman’s lifespan can have enormous benefits in both cardiovascular health and quality of life at large. </p>
<p>Women go through unique stages of life characterized by fluctuating levels of estrogen (such as puberty and menopause) and additional physiological stress on the body (such as pregnancy). With the increasing prevalence of CVD in women, novel sex-related risk factors should be considered in combination with behavioral, environmental, and social factors to guide its early prevention, diagnosis, and treatment in women across all stages of life (Exhibit 2). </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Estrogen corresponds to cardiovascular risk, and the rate of cardiovascular disease in women rises with age." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>Adolescence and puberty mark the first changes</h2>
<p>A woman’s first menstrual period (menarche) usually occurs between the ages of 10 and 16, after a yearlong rise in daily estrogen output.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b17f6569-2ea3-4e08-b259-fbeac3a8b08d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b17f6569-2ea3-4e08-b259-fbeac3a8b08d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Amy E. Lacroix et al., <em>Physiology, Menarche</em>, Treasure Island, FL: StatPearls Publishing, 2023. </span></span></span></a></span> Menstrual cycles have been shown to have an impact on a woman’s CVD risk later in life. </p>
<p>For one, the age of menarche may play a role in CVD risk. A study found that those who had menarche earlier than the age of 12 had an increased risk of CVD and of some of its associated risk factors, such as metabolic syndrome, obesity, and diabetes. The mechanisms linking early menarche and CVD aren’t fully understood but may be explained in part by genetic and lifestyle factors, such as reduced physical activity and excess calorie consumption.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="939cf946-9ad9-4297-88fc-31b8ea2bd79e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="939cf946-9ad9-4297-88fc-31b8ea2bd79e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anna C. O’Kelly et al., “Pregnancy and reproductive risk factors for cardiovascular disease in women,” <em>Circulation Research</em>, February 2022, Volume 130, Number 4; “Sex-specific differences in cardiovascular risk factors and implications for cardiovascular disease prevention in women,” November 2023. </span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>There’s an association between irregular menstrual cycles (affecting around 20 percent of women) and elevated body mass index, total cholesterol, and triglycerides, which may increase the overall risk of CVD. Irregular menstrual cycles also independently contribute to the increased risk of CVD.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8427e374-9bec-4f8b-a917-5f6b42083ccc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8427e374-9bec-4f8b-a917-5f6b42083ccc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Chensihan Huang et al., “Associations of menstrual cycle regularity and length with cardiovascular diseases: A prospective study from UK Biobank,” <em>Journal of the American Heart Association</em>, May 2023, Volume 12, Number 11.</span></span></span></a></span> Potential mechanisms by which irregular or prolonged menstrual cycles affect cardiovascular health include decreased estrogen exposure and shared risk factors, such as obesity. </p>
<p>There’s ample opportunity for research into better understanding the links between menstruation and the overall health of a woman. With greater knowledge and treatment options, women can embark on a lifelong journey to view their heart health more holistically. </p>
<h2>Pregnancy and childbirth can strain a woman’s heart</h2>
<p>Pregnancy puts a physiological strain on a woman’s body, including on her heart. As early as eight weeks into pregnancy, a woman’s body experiences multiple changes, including increased blood volume and increased cardiac output.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cca83b5b-4fc9-44cb-abb5-405c7521c671"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cca83b5b-4fc9-44cb-abb5-405c7521c671" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Priya Soma-Pillay, Catherine Nelson-Piercy, Heli Tolppanen, and Alexandre Mebazaa, “Physiological changes in pregnancy,” <em>Cardiovascular Journal of Africa</em>, 2016, Volume 27, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span> Beyond normal physiological changes during pregnancy, a number of pregnancy-specific conditions have been associated with adverse cardiovascular outcomes. </p>
<p>The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that four out of five maternal deaths in the United States are preventable. The leading cause of these deaths are CVD (cardiac and coronary conditions) (13 percent), thrombotic embolism (9 percent), cardiomyopathy (9 percent) and hypertensive disorders in pregnancy (HDPs) (7 percent).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6b17df52-1836-4187-a56f-fd2fa2a5b117"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6b17df52-1836-4187-a56f-fd2fa2a5b117" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Four in 5 pregnancy-related deaths in the U.S. are preventable,” September 19, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> More than half of pregnancy-related deaths occur in the year after childbirth. Yet up to 40 percent of women don’t access postpartum care, and only an estimated 18 to 25 percent of postpartum patients with pregnancy complications are seen by a primary care provider (PCP) within six months of delivery.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a5d23676-7567-41bf-bd24-19de7ed3aa4e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a5d23676-7567-41bf-bd24-19de7ed3aa4e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jennifer Lewey et al., “Opportunities in the postpartum period to reduce cardiovascular disease risk after adverse pregnancy outcomes: A scientific statement from the American Heart Association,” <em>Circulation</em>, February 2024, Volume 149, Number 7.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Physicians and patients alike must be taught to recognize these issues. Helping pregnant women holistically, beyond reproductive care, creates a vast opportunity to reduce adverse outcomes for mothers and babies. It may also reduce modifiable risk factors for CVD before it’s too late.</p>
<h3>Pregnancy-related hypertensive disorders </h3>
<p>HDPs affect up to 10 percent of pregnant women in the US and are the cause of 7 percent of maternal deaths.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b197b11f-371a-424e-8805-a85e6d133ab6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b197b11f-371a-424e-8805-a85e6d133ab6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, <em>Birth Settings in America: Outcomes, Quality, Access, and Choice</em>, Washington, DC: National Academies Press, 2020. </span></span></span></a></span> HDPs include gestational hypertension (new-onset hypertension of 140 over 90 millimeters of mercury after 20 weeks’ gestation in a previously normotensive woman), chronic hypertension (hypertension before 20 weeks’ gestation), and preeclampsia. Women who develop HDPs in their first pregnancy are at an increased risk of recurrence in subsequent pregnancies. They are also at a higher risk of developing hypertension, stroke, and ischemic heart disease in later life.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d15c3f4a-44f9-42fd-a585-a887af7ba612"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d15c3f4a-44f9-42fd-a585-a887af7ba612" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Gian Francesco Mureddu, “How much does hypertension in pregnancy affect the risk of future cardiovascular events?,” <em>European Heart Journal Supplements</em>, April 2023, Volume 25.</span></span></span></a></span>
</p>
<p>Preeclampsia is a pregnancy-specific condition characterized by hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation and the presence of proteinuria (protein in the urine) and/or end-organ dysfunction.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="520cd123-9ab1-4ab4-ba05-aebf2402ea02"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="520cd123-9ab1-4ab4-ba05-aebf2402ea02" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mariana Garcia et al., “Cardiovascular disease in women: Clinical perspectives,” <em>Circulation Research</em>, April 2016, Volume 118, Number 8.</span></span></span></a></span> The mechanism of preeclampsia isn’t fully understood, and the only definitive cure for the condition is the delivery of the fetus and the placenta.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0038f9e0-5d33-41bc-9a45-df70f9ed627c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0038f9e0-5d33-41bc-9a45-df70f9ed627c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lorena M. Amaral et al., “Pathophysiology and current clinical management of preeclampsia,” <em>Current Hypertension Reports</em>, August 2017, Volume 19, Number 61.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Women with preeclampsia have a fourfold relative risk of developing hypertension later in life, a twofold risk for ischemic heart disease, a twofold relative risk of stroke, and a twofold relative risk for venous thromboembolism (Exhibit 3).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b05373c3-d20e-47c8-b33a-8220b2ff487a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b05373c3-d20e-47c8-b33a-8220b2ff487a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Cardiovascular disease in women,” April 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, the severity of preeclampsia and its earlier onset are correlated with the severity of CVD later in life. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex3-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Preeclampsia is a common pregnancy condition with lasting effects." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex3-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Gestational diabetes</h3>
<p>Gestational diabetes is a pregnancy-specific condition defined as newly diagnosed diabetes mellitus beyond the first trimester of pregnancy. This condition affects up to 14 percent of pregnancies around the world.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c627e1b9-e1d1-421a-9f06-ee961e76432e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c627e1b9-e1d1-421a-9f06-ee961e76432e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Oluwasegun A. Akinyemi, “Profiles and outcomes of women with gestational diabetes mellitus in the United States,” <em>Cureus</em>, July 2023, Volume 15, Number 7.</span></span></span></a></span> Gestational diabetes not only increases the risk of developing type 2 diabetes by sevenfold but also independently raises CVD risk (twofold for stroke and fourfold for myocardial infarction) later in life.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e70109cd-96fb-45ed-85a4-77896d625f9d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e70109cd-96fb-45ed-85a4-77896d625f9d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Cardiovascular disease in women,” April 2016.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<h3>Peripartum cardiomyopathy</h3>
<p>Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a pregnancy-specific condition without a reversible cause. It presents near the end of pregnancy or in the postpartum period in a woman without known heart disease.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9e46c41f-0813-484a-8e03-54b57e40705f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9e46c41f-0813-484a-8e03-54b57e40705f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Laxmi S. Mehta et al., “Cardiovascular considerations in caring for pregnant patients: A scientific statement from the American Heart Association,” <em>Circulation</em>, June 2020, Volume 141, Number 23. </span></span></span></a></span> Although relatively rare (incidence of one in 1,000 to 4,000 US live births), it can carry a high mortality of up to 11 percent in the United States, as shown in a longer-term follow-up study of patients in Midwestern academic centers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="518d3d1a-0d30-43e7-803c-3d10116dba06"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="518d3d1a-0d30-43e7-803c-3d10116dba06" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Peripartum cardiomyopathy,” AHA, updated on May 28, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<h2>Menopause symptoms may play a role in hypertension</h2>
<p>Menopause is a natural part of a woman’s biological aging characterized by the end of the menstrual cycle and reduced estrogen and progesterone. It typically occurs between the ages of 45 and 55. CVD is more common in postmenopausal women than in similarly aged men, though this isn’t the case prior to menopause.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="45c2a0bd-984c-4917-9391-6d98a72d3569"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="45c2a0bd-984c-4917-9391-6d98a72d3569" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Emma Lee et al., “Vasomotor symptoms of menopause, autonomic dysfunction, and cardiovascular disease,” <em>American Journal of Physiology – Heart and Circulatory Physiology</em>, December 2022, Volume 323, Number 6; Anna E. Stanhewicz, Megan M. Wenner, and Nina S. Stachenfeld, “Sex differences in endothelial function important to vascular health and overall cardiovascular disease risk across the lifespan,” <em>American Journal of Physiology – Heart and Circulatory Physiology</em>, November 2018, Volume 315, Number 6. </span></span></span></a></span> Women between the ages of 45 and 65 (around menopausal transition) have the greatest rise in the prevalence of hypertension, yet more research is needed to understand why.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9f486303-f116-4768-8510-49450cbda1b8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9f486303-f116-4768-8510-49450cbda1b8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Vasomotor symptoms of menopause, autonomic dysfunction, and cardiovascular disease,” December 6, 2022. </span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Up to 80 percent of women may experience common menopausal symptoms, such as hot flashes and night sweats. These vasomotor symptoms (VMS) may play a role in hypertension and increased CVD risk. A study showed that women with frequent VMS associated with menopause had a 77 percent higher risk of developing CVD than did women with no or less-frequent VMS.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5866f4d0-d090-4819-b922-e02472ae7a06"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5866f4d0-d090-4819-b922-e02472ae7a06" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Vasomotor symptoms of menopause, autonomic dysfunction, and cardiovascular disease,” December 6, 2022. </span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<h2>CVD disproportionately affects women of color</h2>
<p>When examining women’s cardiovascular health, statistics show how race and ethnicity can also affect women’s healthcare experience. From initial diagnosis to treatment outcomes, women of color often face disparities in care. While some progress has been made, substantial opportunities to address these inequities remain. </p>
<p>In the United States, 59 percent of Black women over the age of 20 have some form of CVD, compared with 43 percent of Hispanic American women, 43 percent of Asian American women, and 42 percent of White women (Exhibit 4).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="53da5ee2-ec00-4804-bb3b-1ca4f97ceb8f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="53da5ee2-ec00-4804-bb3b-1ca4f97ceb8f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“2022 heart disease & stroke statistical update fact sheet, females & cardiovascular diseases*,” AHA, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> American Indian and Native Alaskan women have a prevalence of type 2 diabetes—up to 72 percent in some communities—that’s three times higher than that of White American women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="10c9c0a5-cc1a-486a-9df1-51888bfefe84"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="10c9c0a5-cc1a-486a-9df1-51888bfefe84" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Diabetes and American Indians/Alaska Natives,” US Office of Minority Health, accessed June 2024; Healthy People 2020 Database, CDC, 2021; “Heart health is sub-optimal among American Indian/Alaska Native women, supports needed,” AHA press release, May 31, 2023. </span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Black women in the United States face the highest burden of cardiovascular conditions relative to other cohorts." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Despite having a high prevalence of CVD, persons of African, Hispanic, or Indigenous descent are underrepresented and underreported in US clinical trials.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="641a4fa3-902b-40aa-8832-e845ad1e0110"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">35</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="641a4fa3-902b-40aa-8832-e845ad1e0110" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sujana Balla, Sofia Elena Gomez, and Fatima Rodriguez, “Disparities in cardiovascular care and outcomes for women from racial/ethnic minority backgrounds,” <em>Current Treatment Options in Cardiovascular Medicine</em>, November 2020, Volume 22, Number 75.</span></span></span></a></span> Women of color sit at the intersection of both low representation of women and low representation of non-White races and ethnicities in clinical trials, making their representation in clinical trials even more pertinent. </p>
<p>Black women are at a significantly higher risk than White women of developing CVD during pregnancy, having preterm deliveries, and delivering low-birth-weight infants, and they have the highest postpartum CVD risk, even when adjusted for socioeconomic status.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b0287f1d-0f18-4885-b902-a1c739ebb0c9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">36</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b0287f1d-0f18-4885-b902-a1c739ebb0c9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mohamed M. Gad et al., “Disparities in cardiovascular disease outcomes among pregnant and post-partum women,” <em>Journal of the American Heart Association</em>, December 2020, Volume 10, Number 1; Tracy A. Manuck, “Racial and ethnic differences in preterm birth: A complex, multifactorial problem,” <em>Seminars in Perinatology</em>, December 2017, Volume 41, Number 8.</span></span></span></a></span> In the United States, the incidence of preeclampsia is 60 percent higher in Black women than in White women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a7d424b0-a1ae-474e-95e2-786a20988eca"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">37</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a7d424b0-a1ae-474e-95e2-786a20988eca" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Shanshan Sheehy et al., “Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy and risk of stroke in U.S. Black women,” <em>NEJM Evidence</em>, July 2023, Volume 2, Number 10.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, Black women face more adverse outcomes related to the condition, including kidney damage and mortality.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="59a69d25-5084-499a-8ed5-9f3d7eddcbb7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="59a69d25-5084-499a-8ed5-9f3d7eddcbb7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Disparities in cardiovascular disease outcomes among pregnant and post-partum women,” December 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> American Indian and Native Alaskan women have the highest mortality from peripartum cardiomyopathy (14.5 percent) out of all US ethnic and race groups.</p>
<p>The reasons for these discrepancies are multifactorial and include structural inequalities and <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/consumers-perceptions-of-their-health-related-social-needs">health-related social needs</a>. Addressing biases, providing differential training for those serving these communities, and offering tailored healthcare delivery models that address specific communities would create more equity in care delivery for women of color. </p>
<h2>Cardiovascular research often underrepresents women, resulting in subpar treatment outcomes</h2>
<p>Basic research, including in animal models, often excludes female subjects. One examined compilation of studies published from 2006 to 2016 that focused on preclinical cardiovascular research discovered that the sex of the animals used wasn’t disclosed in 20 percent of the studies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="68f2df6a-ac93-4e48-b613-8b5448f2ca1d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="68f2df6a-ac93-4e48-b613-8b5448f2ca1d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">F. Daniel Ramirez et al., “Sex bias is increasingly prevalent in preclinical cardiovascular research: Implications for translational medicine and health equity for women,” <em>Circulation</em>, February 2017, Volume 135, Number 6.</span></span></span></a></span> Among the studies that did report the sex, only males were used in 72 percent of cases, only females were used in 13 percent of cases, and both sexes were used in 16 percent of cases. Many researchers believe that including females may hamper studies because of the need for larger sample sizes, the increased cost, and the higher variability of female data as a result of the estrous cycle.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fcd64a79-c313-4a8e-a018-23950f2b6944"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fcd64a79-c313-4a8e-a018-23950f2b6944" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Annaliese K. Beery, “Inclusion of females does not increase variability in rodent research studies,” <em>Current Opinion in Behavioral Sciences</em>, October 2018, Volume 23.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Sex should be a consideration as part of initial study design, not only as an afterthought when outcomes differ. For example, between 1997 and 2000, the US Food and Drug Administration removed ten drugs from the market because of adverse events, with one drug noted to have a specific cardiovascular intervention.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="58fbbeb4-ec04-4611-9293-9ede451ee86e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">41</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="58fbbeb4-ec04-4611-9293-9ede451ee86e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Drug safety: Most drugs withdrawn in recent years had greater health risks for women,” US Government Accountability Office, January 19, 2001.</span></span></span></a></span> Eight of those drugs posed greater risks to women than to men, and six correlated with comparatively poorer cardiovascular outcomes in women. </p>
<p>Despite US Congress passing a law in 1993 that required the inclusion of women in clinical research, a gender gap remains. A study looking at 740 trials in cardiovascular health from 2010 to 2017 found that women made up only 38 percent of study participants.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f7c6bfd5-eab8-4a57-8dc1-5539b09b9e6f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">42</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f7c6bfd5-eab8-4a57-8dc1-5539b09b9e6f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Bridget Balch, “Why we know so little about women’s health,” Association of American Medical Colleges, March 26, 2024; Kardie Tobb, Madison Kocher, and Renée P. Bullock-Palmer, “Underrepresentation of women in cardiovascular trials—it is time to shatter this glass ceiling,” <em>American Heart Journal Plus: Cardiology Research and Practice</em>, January 2022, Volume 13; Xurui Jin et al., “Women’s participation in cardiovascular clinical trials from 2010 to 2017,” <em>Circulation</em>, February 2020, Volume 141, Number 7.</span></span></span></a></span> Even after adjusting for prevalence, women were underrepresented in trials related to acute coronary syndrome (ACS), coronary heart disease, and heart failure. Additionally, although postmenopausal women are often the ones most affected by CVD, they also had the lowest study participation rates (26 percent).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="46caa1bc-6267-4d79-82d6-3e08a00551fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">43</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="46caa1bc-6267-4d79-82d6-3e08a00551fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Women’s participation in cardiovascular clinical trials from 2010 to 2017,” February 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> A smaller study, looking at 263 studies as recent as 2016 to 2019, found that women were in slightly less than 42 percent of cardiovascular studies, although 49 percent of the female population had CVD.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="004ebe2e-b584-47d3-aeb9-b586b441265f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">44</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="004ebe2e-b584-47d3-aeb9-b586b441265f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Alexandra Z. Sosinsky et al., “Enrollment of female participants in United States drug and device phase 1–3 clinical trials between 2016 and 2019,” <em>Contemporary Clinical Trials</em>, April 2022, Volume 115.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>The reasons for this are multifactorial, spanning systemic barriers, inadequate trial design, and participant-specific barriers. First and foremost, women need to be asked to participate as routine. Trials need to reflect geographies where a diverse population of women reside or offer alternative means of participation, such as digital engagement. </p>
<p>Furthermore, women often must juggle wage earning with more caretaking responsibilities than men have. Therefore, it’s important to focus on finding ways to lessen the burden of clinical trial participation and address the challenges. Examples include providing assistance for aspects such as travel, transportation, food, eldercare, childcare, and other related expenses if visits to the trial sites are necessary and advancing the acceptability and ease of distributed clinical trials.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="171584d8-84ec-45f9-b716-559734f4ed07"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">45</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="171584d8-84ec-45f9-b716-559734f4ed07" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Barbara E. Bierer et al., “Advancing the inclusion of underrepresented women in clinical research,” <em>Cell Reports Medicine</em>, March 2022, Volume 3, Number 4.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Without enough women participating in trials, researchers have limited data on how treatments and preventative measures affect the female body, especially during transitions that include puberty, pregnancy, and menopause. Consequently, treatment recommendations may not be optimized for women, potentially leading to misdiagnosis and inadequate care. </p>
<p>For example, troponin tests, the gold standard of blood testing for the diagnosis of ACS (conditions characterized by sudden reduced blood supply to the heart), may be underdiagnosing women. Research has demonstrated the upper limits of normal may be twofold higher in men than in women; however, lab standards are based on men, resulting in underdiagnosis of women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c5b1a752-d7da-4800-8779-48ad8f9858ca"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">46</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c5b1a752-d7da-4800-8779-48ad8f9858ca" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Haitham Khraishah et al., “Sex, racial, and ethnic disparities in acute coronary syndrome: Novel risk factors and recommendations for earlier diagnosis to improve outcomes,” <em>Arteriosclerosis, Thrombosis, and Vascular Biology</em>, August 2023, Volume 43, Number 8; Dorien M. Kimenai et al., “Sex-specific versus overall clinical decision limits for cardiac troponin I and T for the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction: A systematic review,” <em>Clinical Chemistry</em>, July 2018, Volume 64, Number 7. </span></span></span></a></span> One study showed that using sex-differentiated troponin levels in testing increased ACS diagnosis in women by 42 percent and 6 percent in men.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="60469bbe-8fb2-4ea2-9fab-87c856c6ace2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">47</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="60469bbe-8fb2-4ea2-9fab-87c856c6ace2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Sex, racial, and ethnic disparities in acute coronary syndrome,” August 2023.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>When looking at common interventions for heart failure, women may experience greater risk, side effects, and even worse outcomes than men do. This finding could be the result of a variety of factors, from differences in body composition to drug metabolism to hormone level fluctuations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="787f4915-2465-4a03-abbf-67a1c6e0c846"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">48</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="787f4915-2465-4a03-abbf-67a1c6e0c846" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">J. Tamargo et al., “Gender differences in the effects of cardiovascular drugs,” <em>European Heart Journal—Cardiovascular Pharmacotherapy</em>, July 2017, Volume 3, Number 3.</span></span></span></a></span> One study found that standard dosing of common cardiac medications (for example, ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, and beta-blockers) resulted in increased drug effect in women than in men at the same dosage, with a higher frequency of side effects.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="533d41f7-6b3a-4d93-9105-d815318f7fae"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">49</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="533d41f7-6b3a-4d93-9105-d815318f7fae" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Giuseppe M. C. Rosano et al., “Gender differences in the effect of cardiovascular drugs: A position document of the Working Group on Pharmacology and Drug Therapy of the ESC,” <em>European Heart Journal</em>, October 2015, Volume 36, Number 40; Bernadet T. Santema et al., “Identifying optimal doses of heart failure medications in men compared with women: A prospective, observational, cohort study,” <em>Lancet</em>, October 2019, Volume 394, Number 10,205.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>Women miss out on sex-appropriate cardiac care because of care delivery gaps </h2>
<p>A lack of knowledge, limited availability of sex- and gender-specific medical education, and various implicit and explicit biases contribute to the inequity in CVD care delivery. </p>
<p>The lack of knowledge persists throughout medical training. One study showed that only 22 percent of PCPs and 42 percent of cardiologists felt extremely well prepared to assess CVD risk in women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="faba20e9-80c9-43e5-8249-426adb8e2d92"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">50</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="faba20e9-80c9-43e5-8249-426adb8e2d92" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs regarding cardiovascular disease in women,” July 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> Indeed, in one survey of over 40 medical schools in Canada and the United States, 70 percent of respondents didn’t formally include sex- or gender-specific content in their curriculum.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f20f5f7d-6a2e-47fd-8b49-24c89cce030f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">51</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f20f5f7d-6a2e-47fd-8b49-24c89cce030f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Najah Adrea et al., “Integration of women’s cardiovascular health content into healthcare provider education: Results of a rapid review and national survey,” <em>CJC Open</em>, February 2024, Volume 6, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span> With many women relying on an ob-gyn as their PCP, sex- and gender-specific cardiovascular training should expand beyond traditional primary care and cardiology training.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c753c996-4edb-440a-858a-458b63c697ba"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">52</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c753c996-4edb-440a-858a-458b63c697ba" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sara Mazzoni et al., “Patient perspectives of obstetrician-gynecologists as primary care providers,” <em>Journal of Reproductive Medicine</em>, January–February 2017, Volume 62, Number 1–2.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Current risk formulas often overlook factors that influence women’s CVD risk—especially those related to menstrual cycles, pregnancy, and menopause (Exhibit 5). Additionally, research suggests that including health-related social needs (such as economic stability, neighborhood safety, and access to quality healthcare) in risk assessments for women, particularly women of color, can provide a more comprehensive picture of CVD risk.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="42445287-964e-4e15-99b6-f52ae6325f2f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">53</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="42445287-964e-4e15-99b6-f52ae6325f2f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Non-biological factors and social determinants of health important in women’s CVD risk assessment,” AHA press release, April 10, 2023; Li Wang et al., “Social determinants of health and hypertension in women compared with men in the United States: An analysis of the NHANES study,” <em>Clinical Cardiology</em>, August 2023, Volume 46, Number 8. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex5-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The opportunity to assess certain sex-specific risk factors for cardiovascular disease exists at each life stage." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20state%20of%20us%20womens%20heart%20health%20a%20path%20to%20improved%20health%20and%20financial%20outcomes/svgz_womenshearthealth_ex5-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Previous research has examined gender disparity in cardiac treatment, particularly in relation to ACS. ACS presentation in men and women often differs. While chest pain is still the most common presentation in both sexes, women often report additional symptoms, such as abdominal pain, jaw pain, nausea, shortness of breath, palpitations, and vomiting.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a8f09255-c800-4f9d-9b80-b99fada25a6a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">54</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a8f09255-c800-4f9d-9b80-b99fada25a6a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Judith H. Lichtman et al., “Sex differences in the presentation and perception of symptoms among young patients with myocardial infarction: Evidence from the VIRGO study (Variation in recovery: Role of gender on outcomes of young AMI patients),” <em>Circulation</em>, February 2018, Volume 137, Number 8. </span></span></span></a></span> In one study, upon presentation to the hospital with chest pain, women were more likely than men to attribute their symptoms to stress or anxiety (20.9 percent versus 11.8 percent). This may result in diagnostic inaccuracies and delayed treatment. </p>
<p>Furthermore, nonspecific electrocardiogram (EKG) changes are more common in women than in men—for example, estrogen-associated EKG changes mimicking ischemia.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d5dcf319-bdd5-4587-ac70-0aee6951920a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">55</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d5dcf319-bdd5-4587-ac70-0aee6951920a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Helena Martínez-Sellés, David Martínez-Sellés, and Manuel Martínez-Sellés, “Sex, lies, and coronary artery disease,” <em>Journal of Clinical Medicine</em>, July 2021, Volume 10, Number 14.</span></span></span></a></span> This may be exacerbated by incorrect placement of the EKG electrodes because of presumed signal reduction by breast tissue.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1d0ad998-4992-46a1-b539-65e439011bc2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">56</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1d0ad998-4992-46a1-b539-65e439011bc2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Pentti M. Rautaharju et al., “A standardized procedure for locating and documenting ECG chest electrode positions: Consideration of the effect of breast tissue on ECG amplitudes in women,” <em>Journal of Electrocardiology</em>, January 1998, Volume 31, Number 1.</span></span></span></a></span> It can potentially be mitigated by ensuring correct positioning using bone landmarks. This can help minimize inaccuracies in the EKG and prevent misdiagnosis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="268c52bc-ecfe-4f93-8e71-1692ede0714d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">57</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="268c52bc-ecfe-4f93-8e71-1692ede0714d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Best practices for ECG lead placement on women,” GE HealthCare, February 16, 2022. </span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
