<p>Women continue to have worse outcomes after ACS compared with men.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7a348e5e-5871-48ea-b057-02bf2ad32393"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">58</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7a348e5e-5871-48ea-b057-02bf2ad32393" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Sex, racial, and ethnic disparities in acute coronary syndrome,” August 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> They’re less likely to undergo coronary revascularization and receive essential ACS treatment at admission or discharge, even when adjusted for demographics, patient characteristics, and type of hospital. Women were 2.5 times less likely than men to be referred to a cardiologist after initial presentation with chest pain in an ambulatory care setting, particularly when the initial diagnosis was undertaken by a male physician.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="823558f7-4064-4184-9797-771aaf41d462"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">59</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="823558f7-4064-4184-9797-771aaf41d462" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Abdullah Al Hamid et al., “Gender bias in diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of cardiovascular diseases: A systematic review,” <em>Cureus</em>, February 2024, Volume 16, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, women treated by female physicians may have a better chance of surviving a heart attack.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6336c199-5ecd-448e-ab66-ae06e9335b06"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">60</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6336c199-5ecd-448e-ab66-ae06e9335b06" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Vera Regitz-Zagrosek and Catherine Gebhard, “Gender medicine: Effects of sex and gender on cardiovascular disease manifestation and outcomes,” <em>Nature Reviews Cardiology</em>, April 2023, Volume 20, Number 4.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Similarly, a study has shown that women were less likely than men to receive more aggressive (and appropriate) risk-factor-modification treatment (for example, statins), particularly when they were treated by a male PCP.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="be27a272-c59c-416b-87cd-44dccd820315"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">61</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="be27a272-c59c-416b-87cd-44dccd820315" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sonya N. Burgess, “Understudied, under-recognized, underdiagnosed, and undertreated: Sex-based disparities in cardiovascular medicine,” <em>Circulation: Cardiovascular Intervention</em>, February 2022, Volume 15, Number 2; Emily S. Lau et al., “Does patient–physician gender concordance influence patient perceptions or outcomes?,” <em>Journal of the American College of Cardiology</em>, March 2021, Volume 77, Number 8; “Women with heart disease are less likely to receive life-saving drugs than men,” European Society of Cardiology press release, April 25, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> A large Canadian study focusing on atrial fibrillation found that male physicians were more likely to overestimate the risk of stroke in men but underestimate it in women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="992d6cf4-1670-45b0-a2bd-929ab0081559"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">62</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="992d6cf4-1670-45b0-a2bd-929ab0081559" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Hanna Lee et al., “Association between patient and physician sex and physician-estimated stroke and bleeding risks in atrial fibrillation,” <em>Canadian Journal of Cardiology</em>, February 2019, Volume 35, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span> In contrast, female physicians could accurately estimate the risk in women but underestimate it in men. </p>
<p>It’s worth noting that even though half of medical-school graduates are women, women currently make up only 15 percent of adult cardiologists and 4 percent of interventional cardiologists in the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d6814501-8741-4149-b30b-132584a3d6a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">63</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d6814501-8741-4149-b30b-132584a3d6a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Parham Eshtehardi et al., “Women leaders: Transforming the culture in cardiology,” <em>Open Heart</em>, February 2022, Volume 9, Number 1.</span></span></span></a></span> Research conducted by the American College of Cardiology reported that almost two-thirds of female cardiologists consistently experienced discrimination at work, mostly related to gender and childbirth.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cfaec62d-567d-4088-aec3-c5f2d9641222"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">64</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cfaec62d-567d-4088-aec3-c5f2d9641222" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Marwah Shahid, “Addressing the underrepresentation of women in cardiology through tangible opportunities for mentorship and leadership,” <em>Methodist DeBakey Cardiovascular Journal</em>, January–March 2019, Volume 15, Number 1.</span></span></span></a></span> Less than a quarter of men reported discrimination, which was largely in relation to race and religion rather than gender. </p>
<p>A survey of internal medicine trainees found that having a positive role model was the most important professional development need for both men and women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e4852a6e-47ab-4f62-ae3e-51b0be27fc74"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">65</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e4852a6e-47ab-4f62-ae3e-51b0be27fc74" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Meghan York et al., “Professional preferences and perceptions of cardiology among internal medicine residents: Temporal trends over the past decade,” <em>JAMA Cardiology</em>, December 2022, Volume 7, Number 12. </span></span></span></a></span> A significant majority of women felt that the field of cardiology lacked the positive role models they were looking for. This lack of role models, combined with discrimination, may discourage potential candidates from entering the field and perpetuate low rates of women serving as mentors for future trainees. </p>
<p>These biases extend beyond the clinical setting. Women are less likely than men to receive bystander cardiopulmonary resuscitation in case of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, resulting in lower survival to discharge (the odds ratio for men to women is 1.27). <span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="429abc5c-636a-4321-acbf-65f9f0ff95d1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">66</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="429abc5c-636a-4321-acbf-65f9f0ff95d1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Audrey L. Blewer et al., “Gender disparities among adult recipients of bystander cardiopulmonary resuscitation in the public,” <em>Circulation: Cardiovascular Quality and Outcomes</em>, August 2018, Volume 11, Number 8. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The use of AI in healthcare has seen a dramatic increase in recent years. Some uses show great promise. In one study, clinical-decision-making accuracy in chest pain evaluation was improved with the assistance of AI, without introducing or exacerbating existing gender biases.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="97219479-9ca2-4ff5-8b8e-4ac4e4e9a4e1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">67</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="97219479-9ca2-4ff5-8b8e-4ac4e4e9a4e1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ethan Goh et al., “ChatGPT influence on medical decision-making, bias, and equity: A randomized study of clinicians evaluating clinical vignettes,” medRxiv, November 2023, Volume 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Amid busy schedules, clinicians often don’t have the time to stay on top of the latest research and clinical guidelines, so using AI tools as prompts to ask pertinent questions in a consultation (for example, assessing a woman’s menopausal history as part of a comprehensive CVD risk assessment) could be a viable solution. </p>
<p>However, machine learning models that are trained on data sets containing primarily men can result in suboptimal results, mistakes, and discriminatory outcomes, because they do not consider the sex and gender differences in health and disease.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="434de6d2-bfa2-4e0e-976f-94b9eee33558"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">68</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="434de6d2-bfa2-4e0e-976f-94b9eee33558" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Davide Cirillo et al., “Sex and gender differences and biases in artificial intelligence for biomedicine and healthcare,” <em>NPJ Digital Medicine</em>, June 2020, Volume 3; Agostina J. Larrazabal et al., “Gender imbalance in medical imaging datasets produces biased classifiers for computer-aided diagnosis,” <em>Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America</em>, June 2020, Volume 117, Number 23.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>Innovation and investment in women’s heart health could make a difference</h2>
<p>All ecosystem stakeholders could play a role in integrating a sex-specific lens at the onset of trial design, incorporating it into innovation design, testing, and launch. To continue discovering the most effective CVD prevention methods and interventions for women, greater investment in both women’s heart health and heart health overall is needed. CVD research funding made up less than 6 percent of the US National Institutes of Health (NIH) budget in 2022, with only a fifth of that dedicated to women’s heart health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dbb3ab56-83c4-431b-9261-a508f5d87bdb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">69</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dbb3ab56-83c4-431b-9261-a508f5d87bdb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Budget,” US National Institutes of Health (NIH), October 4, 2023; <em>Report of the Advisory Committee on Research on Women’s Health: Fiscal years 2021–2022</em>, NIH, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> That category includes, for example, conditions that may be unique to women or more prevalent in women than in men for which medical interventions may be different or there has been insufficient clinical data on women. </p>
<p>Women primarily drive 80 percent of healthcare decisions and spending for their families.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="89efae9f-78f0-4269-ad7e-808e8f7ed1de"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">70</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="89efae9f-78f0-4269-ad7e-808e8f7ed1de" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sabrina Matoff-Stepp et al., “Women as health care decision-makers: Implications for health care coverage in the United States,” <em>Journal of Health Care for the Poor and Underserved</em>, November 2014, Volume 25, Number 4.</span></span></span></a></span> However, investments continue deprioritizing sex-specific care. As biopharma companies are exploring new mechanisms of action for novel cardiovascular therapies, they can be leaders in developing sex-specific strategies, from R&D to commercialization. For example, they can aim to understand the biological impacts on women of drug metabolism, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacokinetics. Biopharma companies can also embrace a strategy for women’s heart health that extends beyond the cardiovascular system. This would require acknowledging the overlap between therapeutic areas and cross-therapeutic area expansion (for example, into cardiovascular, metabolic, renal, and other areas).</p>
<p>In addition to expanding sex-segregated R&D across emerging clinical interventions that benefit both women and men, increased investment is needed for female-specific heart health conditions (for example, preeclampsia). In 2020, only 1 percent of healthcare research and innovation was invested in female-specific conditions beyond oncology.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d163b4b7-7be3-4058-ae00-45f1ad2243de"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">71</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d163b4b7-7be3-4058-ae00-45f1ad2243de" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/unlocking-opportunities-in-womens-healthcare">Unlocking opportunities in women’s healthcare</a>,” McKinsey, February 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Venture capital investment in women’s health has increased 314 percent over the past five years; however, investment in FemTech (diagnostic tools, products, services, wearables, and software that use technology to address women’s health issues) makes up 2 percent of the overall health sector.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6002207c-6924-4222-ba5e-55d05a030458"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">72</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6002207c-6924-4222-ba5e-55d05a030458" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Phalguni Deswal, “FemTech: The world’s largest ‘niche’ market,” Medical Device Network, March 8, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Women make up 13 percent of start-up founders overall yet were 24 percent of FemTech founders in 2022—a rate that declined to 22 percent in 2023.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6d9c8d17-3e13-423b-92ea-30f1ab950a4f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">73</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6d9c8d17-3e13-423b-92ea-30f1ab950a4f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kevin Dowd, “A sector-by-sector guide to the gender gap among startup founders,” Carta, January 17, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Since women only receive 2 percent of total venture capital funding in the United States,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1760c825-870c-451f-9b0a-e3f3dc32a30c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">74</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1760c825-870c-451f-9b0a-e3f3dc32a30c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sara Silano, “Women founders get 2% of venture capital funding in U.S.,” Morningstar, March 6, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> this puts FemTech at a potentially greater disadvantage. </p>
<p>In parallel, research suggests that cardiovascular-health-related start-ups and innovations receive less funding than other major therapeutic areas do.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ada10283-7b3e-48db-b64f-cd45e0c2c3ba"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">75</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ada10283-7b3e-48db-b64f-cd45e0c2c3ba" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Christopher Colecchi and David Tancredi, “Broadview Ventures: Investing in the future of cardiovascular technology,” <em>JACC: Basic to Translational Science</em>, February 2016, Volume 1, Number 1–2.</span></span></span></a></span> And when they do receive funding, it’s mostly in digital health or data-driven business models, suggesting that start-ups with a cardiovascular focus outside of these fields may continue to be underfunded.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="24a30ffb-4b3a-4ca8-ab36-b9fab06015d3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">76</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="24a30ffb-4b3a-4ca8-ab36-b9fab06015d3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“What drives innovation in cardiovascular health?,” AHA, accessed June 2024.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Female leadership across healthcare research and delivery matters. While women make up the <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/women-in-healthcare-and-life-sciences-the-ongoing-stress-of-covid-19">vast majority of the US healthcare workforce</a>, only about a third of US hospitals are led by women, and less than 15 percent of system CEO roles are filled by women.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0c375c4a-4913-4338-b706-8291c2acfa56"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">77</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0c375c4a-4913-4338-b706-8291c2acfa56" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>American Hospital Statistics</em>, 2017 edition, American Hospital Association, January 2017; Jason N. Mose, “Representation of women in top executive positions in general medical-surgical hospitals in the United States,” <em>Women’s Health Reports</em>, May  2021, Volume 2, Number 1.</span></span></span></a></span> A study across 4,271 medical products demonstrated that boards with women participating as directors announced recalls about four weeks earlier than boards with all men did.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="94c47549-3e9b-485e-b0d2-72b5af56d476"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">78</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="94c47549-3e9b-485e-b0d2-72b5af56d476" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Corinne Post et al., “Dangerous products recalled faster when women are on the board,”<em> I by IMD</em>, March 24, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> With a lower number of women in decision-making positions, there might be a blind spot regarding the potential and importance of women’s health innovations, especially in conditions such as CVD that have been primarily associated with men.</p>
<p>As a note, the investment landscape for FemTech is still nascent, with most companies in that field focused on maternal health, menstrual health, and fertility. Although there’s a growing opportunity to address women’s health beyond female-specific conditions, such as in cardiovascular health, fewer than 20 early-stage companies focus on women’s cardiac health—and the majority of those focus on maternal cardiac health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f7a9f02e-414b-4d75-8e23-e9a33c855cc7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">79</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f7a9f02e-414b-4d75-8e23-e9a33c855cc7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">PitchBook, accessed February 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> While FemTech funding has continued to increase, there’s still a lag in funding for women’s cardiovascular health. </p>
<h2>Recommended actions to close the gap </h2>
<p>Improving women’s cardiovascular-health outcomes will require prioritization and a strategic investment of resources, leadership, and dedicated time across all areas of health. Despite rising awareness over the past decades about the importance of recognizing women’s heart health, an economic opportunity amounting to $28 billion still exists to prevent the 1.6 million years of life lost because of poor health or premature deaths in women in the United States. </p>
<p>Stakeholders in the public and private sectors, including employers, not-for-profit organizations, and researchers, have an opportunity to embrace the business of better health. By addressing the existing gap and moving closer to achieving a healthier population, with a specific focus on women’s heart health across all age groups, everyone could benefit. </p>
<h3>Advance sex-specific research from basic sciences to clinical trials</h3>
<p>Research could be meaningfully improved by shifting from a one-size-fits-all approach to prioritizing sex-specific differences:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Developing more <em>knowledge around women and heart disease</em> relies on a deeper understanding of biological differences. Future research could provide a crucial recognition of the distinctive vulnerabilities that women face across their lives, including during pregnancy.</li>
    <li>Revamping and expanding <em>clinical research initiatives</em> may include conducting clinical trials specifically focused on women at all stages of life. Validating women-centric diagnostic tools and investigating the impact of CVD on vulnerable and intersectional populations could also improve care delivery. </li>
    <li>Additional <em>transparency and disclosure</em> within research, drugs, and devices could lead to national dashboards on giving evidence on sex-based differences. As the evidence base becomes more robust, it could be built into clinical guidelines.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Improve routine health data collection, diagnostics, and treatment algorithms</h3>
<p>Effective guidelines and algorithms rely on a foundation of comprehensive data collection and a balanced representation of women across all age groups and health conditions. Collecting women-specific data in a standardized, easily digestible format should become routine. For example, the NIH has branded menstrual cycle information as the “fifth vital sign.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a8327c7c-bd92-46cd-b144-97a61a7328ba"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">80</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a8327c7c-bd92-46cd-b144-97a61a7328ba" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Menstrual cycles as a fifth vital sign,” Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, September 13, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Potential avenues to improve routine health data collection and diagnostics include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Improved diagnostic criteria for women and separate treatment pathways for men and women. </em>There also may be applicability for other specialties—for example, one study found that breast arterial calcification, picked up on routine mammograms, may be a useful surrogate for atherosclerotic cardiac disease.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c3d96f98-3d10-4469-b91d-01ba452bb60d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">81</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c3d96f98-3d10-4469-b91d-01ba452bb60d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Carlos Iribarren et al., “Breast arterial calcification: A novel cardiovascular risk enhancer among postmenopausal women,” <em>Circulation: Cardiovascular Imaging</em>, March 2022, Volume 15, Number 3.</span></span></span></a></span> </li>
    <li><em>Interoperable wearables that deliver information to providers.</em> Smartphone apps to track heart health, telemedicine, heart health consultations, and wearable devices all empower individuals to keep track of their health. Future efforts may include that data being shared or flagged to a provider if something appears concerning. </li>
    <li><em>AI assistance.</em> As use of AI accelerates in healthcare settings, institutions could consider setting up continuous monitoring and evaluation of these novel technologies. Such efforts are essential to ensure their effectiveness in improving women’s cardiovascular-health outcomes, access, and care experience.</li>
</ul>
<p>In all efforts to improve data collection, patient privacy must be paramount. All US-based companies should follow regulations such as the Health Breach Notification Rule, Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 rules, 21st Century Cures Act, and Code of Federal Regulations on information blocking.</p>
<h3>Equip healthcare providers across the care continuum </h3>
<p>Healthcare providers across the spectrum, including neurologists, PCPs, and ob-gyns, to name a few, could view women’s cardiovascular health as a shared responsibility to improve outcomes. Imagine, for example, creating a standard postpartum health visit that focused on not just the baby or the mom’s obstetric needs but also a comprehensive cardiovascular “debrief” from any high-risk events occurring during pregnancy. </p>
<p>Other actions may include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Training on how to identify and mitigate potential biases within the healthcare setting. </em>Hospital systems can further strengthen this approach by creating women’s health programs that bring together specialties such as cardiology, obstetrics–gynecology, oncology, and primary care. These specialists could not only serve patients but act as educational hubs for other providers within the hospital setting. </li>
    <li><em>Expansion of the role that allied healthcare practitioners play in the management of CVD.</em> Many people, such as doulas, midwives, and community workers, can be involved in cardiovascular care in women. For example, tailored, patient-centric, nurse-led interventions focused on self-management strategies have been shown to encourage a sense of ownership over a patient’s health journey and increase the likelihood of sustained positive behavior.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a6f6df08-117f-4e46-b7e0-bd1ba1b682c1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">82</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a6f6df08-117f-4e46-b7e0-bd1ba1b682c1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lemma N. Bulto and Jeroen M. Hendriks, “The role of nurse-led interventions to empower patients in cardiovascular care,” <em>European Journal of Cardiovascular Nursing</em>, March 2024, Volume 23, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<h3>Raise public awareness on heart health, and tailor prevention strategies across a lifespan</h3>
<p>Public-education campaigns continue to play a valuable role in cardiovascular health. Culturally sensitive, accessible materials that raise awareness about risk factors, prevention strategies, and resources can be tailored to help those at risk of developing CVD. There are several additional ways that outreach could occur:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Educational institutions.</em> This includes teaching sex-based differences, including challenges and opportunities related to women-specific care delivery, in medical-school curricula and throughout medical residency.</li>
    <li><em>Direct to consumer.</em> Engaging women through trusted channels in the moments that matter. Outreach can occur during pregnancy using pregnancy-specific apps. Baby boomers are the most likely to be on certain social media sites, so using those sites to provide resources within the fields of heart health and menopause may benefit women of that generation. </li>
    <li><em>Employers.</em> Workplace wellness programs can equip employees with the knowledge and tools to prioritize their heart health, potentially improving overall quality of life and removing absenteeism. Additionally, employers have opportunities to improve health through six modifiable drivers: economic security, mindsets and beliefs, productive activity, sleep, social interaction, and stress.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c1f7e1b7-d6c9-4f9d-9284-606e0bd1985c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">83</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c1f7e1b7-d6c9-4f9d-9284-606e0bd1985c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jacqueline Brassey, Lars Hartenstein, Barbara Jeffery, and Patrick Simon, “<a href="/mhi/our-insights/working-nine-to-thrive">Working nine to thrive</a>,” MHI, March 13, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, employers can examine their boards and C-suites to assess whether they’re meeting their vision of a diverse and <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-organization-blog/inclusive-workplaces-focus-on-management-practices-that-matter-not-fluff">inclusive workplace</a>.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Invest in furthering women’s heart health</h3>
<p>Investing in businesses and initiatives that improve women’s cardiovascular health could have benefits for patients, society, and investors. By addressing the unmet needs in women’s heart health, businesses can make a substantial  impact on the lives of women and potentially tap into a large, underserved market. Here are some items to consider:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Life science investors that focus on large, underserved markets (such as both heart health and associated conditions) could benefit from the <em>relative lack of other players</em> in this area. Most investments in women’s health have historically focused on reproductive health. </li>
    <li>Employers that focus on heart health through workplace wellness programs or other initiatives could benefit from <em>reduced absenteeism</em> and potentially lower the healthcare costs associated with chronic conditions. </li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>With 60 million US women living with CVD, the time to act is now. Despite recent advances, a  health gap in CVD for women still exists. It’s underpinned by limited understanding of the biological differences of women from men and their impact on CVD; women’s underrepresentation in clinical research; lower effectiveness of CVD prevention, diagnosis in women compared with men; and poorer care delivery for women compared with men. Addressing the gap by 2040 could give an annual 1.6 million years of life lost because of poor health or early death back to women. In parallel, it could boost the US economy by $28 billion and the global economy by at least $80 billion. </p>
<p>Closing the woman’s health gap in CVD can’t be done singlehandedly overnight. It will require a consistent and collective effort from various stakeholders, including community leaders, governments, healthcare institutions, individuals, investors, medical and nursing education boards, and workplaces. As women are often the cornerstones of their families, communities, and workplaces, addressing their health equity could have far-reaching effects on all strata of society. This can begin by reframing women’s heart health as a problem for everyone to tackle, not as a “women’s problem.”</p>
<p>Women’s heart health can be improved at every stage of life, and the wide gap reflects tremendous opportunity to improve the quality of life for every woman in the United States. In a new era, the burden of CVD could be erased, and women could better lend their talents, energy, and leadership to every sector of society. By prioritizing accessible healthcare, education, and research related to women’s heart health, a future is possible where millions of women not only live longer, healthier lives, but also contribute their full potential to a thriving global society.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/lucy-perez">Lucy Pérez</a></strong> is a leader of the McKinsey Health Institute (MHI) and a senior partner in McKinsey’s Boston office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/megan-ann-greenfield">Megan Greenfield</a></strong> is a partner and an MHI-affiliated leader.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Alysha de Souza, Anastasia Perez Ternent, Anouk Petersen, Brad Herbig, Devika Sandill, Grail Dorling, Isabella Tagliaferri, Joachim Bleys, Kate Midden, Maria Mandel, Natalia Camargo, Pooja Kumar, Sarah Pickard, and Valentina Sartori for their contributions to this report.</p>
<p>They also wish to thank Claire Kinzy, Jennifer Hall, Juliana Crawford, Lisa Suennen, Mariell Jessup, and Nancy Brown from the American Heart Association for their contributions to this report. </p>
<hr>
<p>This report was edited by Elizabeth Newman, an executive editor in the Chicago office.</p>
<hr>
<p><em>This report reflects women’s health as a market segment. For the purposes of this report, the term “woman” was applied to any individual assigned female at birth and includes those under the age of 18. The authors acknowledge the importance of healthcare to the gender-fluid, nonbinary, and transgender communities and that not all people who identify as women are assigned female at birth.</em></p>
<p><em>The authors have used the phrase “sex and gender” to reflect inclusive language and recognize the need for future research into health issues that’s inclusive of the gender-fluid, nonbinary, and transgender communities. They also acknowledge the profound health differences among women based on factors such as age, disability, ethnicity, race, sexual orientation, and socioeconomic status. Additional work and research should reflect on how to tackle these components alongside the overall women’s health gap.</em></p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid
